arch:property.oc:show_val: Opening elevation: 893.179 m in northwest, 893.758 m in northeast.
Portico Wall and doorway through wall.

Phase II: First period of major Nabataean construction at the Great Temple complex in the 1st c. BCE. Portico Wall of the Propylaeum built. Construction of the lowest eight steps leading up from the then sand and gravel path to a landing, which may have been the site of an early altar.

The Portico Wall, a massively-built sandstone wall oriented east west and forming, in essence, the northern boundary of the trench. The exposed north face (fronting on the Roman Street) shows large brownish-red sandstone blocks, expertly dressed, laid very well with some evidence of mortar. The south face is obscured by a late wall built flush against it. The wall is more well-preserved on the west, tapering down to only one or two courses preserved over the string course on the east.

oc:metadata.dc:title: Petra Great Temple Excavations: Locus 15 (Locus)
